Appropriate mechanisms are in place to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response.
Annual emergency response coordination activities are performed (Section 1.5.1).
Annual notification exercises are performed (Section 1.5.2).

1.5.1 Emergency Response Coordination Activities

The purpose of emergency response coordination activities is to coordinate response needs with local emergency planning and response organizations. The intent is for local response organizations to be made aware of the regulated substance at Fresh Innovations, their quantities, the risks presented by the covered processes, and the resources and capabilities at our facility to respond to an accidental release of a regulated substance. The emergency response coordination activities will consist of the following:
Coordinations will be completed at least annually. Additional coordinations will be made to account for changes at our facility that may affect the community emergency response plan.
Coordinations will include Fresh Innovationss emergency response plan, updated emergency contact information, and any other information necessary for developing and implementing the local emergency response plan.

Coordination activities will be appropriately documented. The coordination records will include the names of individuals involved and their contact information (phone number, email address, and organizational affiliations), dates of coordination activities, and nature of coordination activities.

The disclosure of information classified or restricted by the Department of Defense or other Federal agencies or contractors of such agencies is controlled by applicable laws, regulations, or executive orders concerning the release of that classified or restricted information.

1.5.2 Emergency Response Notification Exercises

At least once per calendar year, Fresh Innovations will conduct an exercise of the facilitys

Executive Summary

This program is intended to meet the spirit and intent of the following regulations:
California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program  Title 19 CCR, Division 5, Chapter 2
Federal EPA Risk Management Program (RMP)  Title 40 CFR §68
California Process Safety Management (PSM) Program  Title 8 CCR §5189
Federal Process Safety Management (PSM) Program  Title 29 CFR §1910.119

Hereafter this program will be referred to as the RMP/PSM/CalARP Program.

This program is intended to be a living document. As such, the information, procedures, policies, and documentation that make up this program must be made easily accessible and updated as necessary. To accomplish this, Fresh Innovations has elected to use PSMWriter, software developed and distributed by Resource Compliance, Inc. This software will assist us with updating, maintaining, scheduling, and tracking RMP/PSM/CalARP related activities. 

1.1 Fresh Innovations, Risk and Process Safety Management Program

This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that Fresh Innovations has updated their unified RMP/PSM/CalARP Program. This program has been prepared to address the risks involved in operating and maintaining the following process which has the presence of hazardous chemicals above threshold quantities: 

Process Name                        | Process Chemical              | Process Quantity(lbs.)
Ammonia Refrigeration       Anhydrous Ammonia           15,200

Our RMP/PSM/CalARP Program promotes overall plant, worker, public, and environmental safety. The program enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of hazardous chemicals. Overall, the program is designed to prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and physical property damage.

Our company has many policies and procedures in place to promote overall plant, worker and public safety. We have: 
Prepared a unified program based on the PSM regulati

on to meet CalARP and RMP obligations as well
Organized the program so that it meshes closely with general business practices
Utilized PSMWriter software to ensure that all necessary employees have access to relevant information (SOPs, PHAs, audits, etc.)
The RMP/PSM/CalARP Program sets forth rules, procedures, and practices that will help our employees and neighbors protect themselves.

1.2 Process Description

Facility Overview

Fresh Innovations operates a commercial food processing plant for apples in Stockton, CA. The facility has an ammonia refrigeration system that provides refrigeration capacity to the following:
(1) Finished Product Room 
(1) Processing Room
(1) Shipping Room

Facility Location

Fresh Innovations is located at 7735 S Highway 99 Stockton, CA 95215. The latitude and longitude of the machinery area is 37.890583, -121.222119. The facility is located on the west side of State Highway 99 in a rural area surrounded by the Stockton Metropolitan Airport and agricultural land.

According to FEMA Flood Map Service, the facility is located in an area of minimal flood hazard.
Fresh Innovations is not located in an Alquist-Priolo Fault Zone as defined by the California Department of Conservation. In addition, a review of United States Geological Survey (USGS) fault maps revealed that there are no faults in close proximity to the site. The USGS 2018 One-Year Model revealed that Fresh Innovations had a 1-2% chance of experiencing potentially minor-damage due to ground shaking in 2018.

The USGS 2023 50-State Long-term National Seismic Hazard Model revealed that Fresh Innovations has a 25-50% chance of slight (or greater) damaging earthquake shaking in 100 years.

Description of Covered Process

The air-cooling evaporators in Processing and Finished Product Rooms are supplied from flooded accumulators while the air-cooling evaporators in the Shipping Room are supplied by a subcooler or high pressure receiver. Heat exchangers in the Processing Room are

supplied by a recirculator. As such, the system is configured for direct-expansion, flooded and pumped overfeed operation.

Control valve groups are located on the roof, in the attic space, and alongside their evaporators to provide easy access. The refrigeration machinery is contained within or directly above the machinery room. A partial list of system components includes: 

Machinery Room
(4) Screw compressors
(3) Oil separators
(3) Shell and tube oil coolers
(1) High pressure receiver
(1) Liquid transfer vessel
(1) Main suction accumulator
(1) Thermosyphon vessel
Facility Roof 
(2) Evaporative condensers
(2) Plate and frame heat exchangers (subcoolers)
(4) Accumulators
Shipping Room
(4) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)
Processing Room
(6) Air-cooling evaporators (ceiling-suspended)
(4) Shell and tube chillers
(1) Falling film water chiller
Finished Product Room
(4) Air-cooling evaporators (bunker-mounted, spiral fin)

Process Classification

The ammonia refrigeration system at Fresh Innovations consists of vessels, equipment, and valves which are interconnected by piping. As such, the refrigeration system at Fresh Innovations is treated as a single process.

1.3 General Accident Release & Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

1.3.1 General 

We inform our employees engaged in process operations of the dangers of an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia in annual safety meetings. During these meetings we also discuss preventative measures, such as evacuation, in order to be prepared for a release.

Fresh Innovations has also conducted an off-site consequence analysis of worst-case and alternative release scenarios for the ammonia refrigeration process. These are for the purposes of informing the public in the event of an accidental release. The results of the analyses are reported in PSMWriter and hard copy binders. 

1.3.2 Anhydrous Ammonia

The ammonia refrigeration process at the Fresh Innovations facility is an integral part of the overall busines

s and operates most of the year. It is extremely important that this process is maintained and operated in a safe and efficient manner. Management is committed to making sure that employees are made aware of the potential danger of an ammonia leak.

Our refrigeration personnel monitor the ammonia refrigeration process and keep active records of all procedures and transactions that pertain to ammonia. In addition, the process is checked frequently by one of the outside refrigeration contractors that we use. These contractors also assist in performing the annual mechanical integrity inspection of our ammonia equipment. 

1.4 Five Year Accident History

Fresh Innovations has had no accidental release within the last five (5) years.

1.5 Emergency Action and Response Plan

Fresh Innovationss emergency action and response program has been developed to satisfy the following requirements:
Cal/OSHAs Emergency Action Plan  Title 8 CCR §3220
U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administrations (OSHA) Emergency Action Plans  Title 29 CFR §1910.38
Cal/OSHAs Process Safety Management [Emergency Response Program Requirements]  Title 8 CCR §5189(n)
U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administrations (OSHA) Process Safety Management [Emergency Planning and Response Requirements]  Title 29 CFR §1910.119(n)
California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements]  Title 19 CCR, Division 5, Chapter 2 §5120.1-5120.2
USEPA Risk Management Program [Emergency Response Program Requirements]  Title 40 CFR §68.90-96
California Hazardous Materials Business Plan (HMBP) [Emergency Response Plans and Procedures]  Title 19 CCR, Division 5, Chapter 1 §5030.7
Strategically, Fresh Innovations has chosen to be a non-responding stationary source. Our employees will not respond to accidental releases of ammonia. In lieu of responding to accidental releases, Fresh Innovations is implementing the following protocols:
The facility is included in the co

emergency response notifications mechanism. The facility will record each notification exercise utilizing PSMWriter.

Alternatively, the facility may meet the notification requirements through other exercises conducted to meet other Federal, state or local requirements, provided that the necessary notification is performed. Additionally, if a notification is made in response to an accidental release, this would also satisfy the notification requirement.

1.6 Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Fresh Innovations has implemented many policies and procedures to promote overall plant, worker, public, and environmental safety. Nevertheless, Fresh Innovations continually strives to improve in all areas, including safety.

By utilizing PSMWriter software, all necessary employees have access to every aspect of the RMP/PSM/CalARP Program. This has improved Fresh Innovationss ability to communicate hazardous situations to employees and contractors. In addition, PSMWriter tracks all RMP/PSM/CalARP related events so that Fresh Innovationss management team can ensure that the RMP/PSM/CalARP Program is being implemented.

Fresh Innovations has implemented all aspects of the RMP/PSM/CalARP Program. When a RMP/PSM/CalARP Program requirement is completed (i.e. mechanical integrity inspection, process hazard analysis, compliance audit, etc.) any specific action items related to that event are entered into PSMWriter, assigned a responsible person, and given a due date. Once the action item has been completed, the resolution can be documented using PSMWriter as well. A list of current or past due action items can be accessed at any time by those with access to PSMWriter.

In addition to utilizing PSMWriter to create, schedule, track, and document events, Fresh Innovations has also entered into a contract with Resource Compliance to obtain help with RMP/PSM/CalARP Program implementation.

Fresh Innovations considers the RMP/PSM/CalARP Program a living document. It is an interactive f

ramework that guides safe action for Fresh Innovations employees, but allows for feedback and continual improvement. Through the RMP/PSM/CalARP Program Fresh Innovations will continue to maintain overall plant worker, public, and environmental safety.
